title-group.article-title: The Monetary Costs of Crime to Middle Adulthood
title-group.subtitle: Findings from the Cambridge Study in Delinquent Development

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Alex R. Piquero is Ashbel Smith Professor of Criminology at the University of Texas at Dallas, Adjunct Professor Key Centre for Ethics, Law, Justice, and Governance, Griffith University Australia, and Co-Editor, Journal of Quantitative Criminology. His research interests include criminal careers, criminological theory, and quantitative research methods. He has received several research, teaching, and service awards and is Fellow of both the American Society of Criminology and the Academy of Criminal Justice Sciences.

Wesley G. Jennings, PhD, is an assistant professor in the College of Behavioral and Community Sciences in the Department of Criminology and has a courtesy assistant professor appointment in the Department of Mental Health Law and Policy at the University of South Florida. He received his doctorate degree in criminology from the University of Florida in 2007. He has published over 65 peer-reviewed articles, and his major research interests include longitudinal data analysis, semi-parametric group-based modeling, sex offending, gender, and race/ethnicity.

David Farrington is O.B.E., is professor of Psychological Criminology at the Institute of Criminology, Cambridge University and Adjunct Professor of Psychiatry at Western Psychiatric Institute and Clinic, University of Pittsburgh. His major research interest is in developmental criminology, and he is Director of the Cambridge Study in Delinquent Development, which is a prospective longitudinal survey of over 400 London males from age 8 to age 48. In addition to 540 published journal articles and book chapters on criminological and psychological topics, he has published 82 books, monographs and government publications.

abstract.p: Objectives: Monetary cost estimates of criminal careers have been limited to specific samples, specific ages, and focused on the United States. This article is the first to examine the costs of a life course of crime in the United Kingdom. Method: This study uses longitudinal data from 411 South London males from the Cambridge Study in Delinquent Development (CSDD) to derive costs-of-crime estimates from childhood to middle adulthood (ages 10 to 50). Additional features include a calculation of cost estimates across distinct offending trajectories and centering on costs per offender. Results: Offending over the life course imposes a considerable amount of economic and social costs and these costs are differentially distributed across offending trajectories. The cost of high-rate chronic offending is nearly two and a half to ten times greater than the cost of high adolescence peaked offending, very low-rate chronic offending, and low adolescence peaked offending, respectively. It is estimated that a male high-rate chronic offender on average would impose an annual cost of £18 ($29) per U.K. citizen or a lifetime cost of £742 ($1,185) per U.K. citizen. Conclusions: As the average and total costs of crime were significantly different across offending trajectories, with high-rate chronics imposing the most financial burden, adopting prevention and intervention strategies aimed at reducing the number of high-rate chronics and/or speeding up their eventual desistance will offer many savings to the public and perhaps turn those negative costs into positive contributions.

body.p: When the public is asked about their perception of crime, they often tend to espouse some very hard-line views of why offenders commit crime and how the criminal justice system should respond with various punishments (Cullen, Fisher, and Applegate 2000; Roberts and Stalans 1997). The public, however, does not have a good grasp on what it costs to mete out punishment and only recently have researchers started to ask the public about their willingness to pay for criminal justice decisions (Cohen et al. 2004; Ludwig and Cook 2001; Nagin et al. 2006).

Research on the cost of crime emerged in the late 1980s (Aos 1999; Cohen 1988; Cohen, Miller, and Rossman 1994; Miller, Cohen, and Wiersema 1996; Schweinhart, Barnes, and Weikart 1993). These studies led to additional research by Anderson (1999) and others, who also summarized the total costs of crime to include those costs outside the criminal justice system (e.g., victim losses, crime prevention strategies, opportunity costs of victims', criminals', and prisoners' time, the fear of being victimized, and the costs of deterrence). In Anderson’s study of data mainly from 1997, he estimated crime costs to exceed $1 trillion annually for the entire United States. If one were to take the U.S. population from 1997, we would arrive at a crime cost of $3,731.97 per U.S. citizen regardless of age.1

Other research on cost estimates expanded these early studies by examining different crime types and expanding the various inputs into the cost estimates to include expenses such as direct and indirect, tangible and intangible costs, such as medical care, mental health treatment, and counseling, property loss, employment loss, overall quality of life, emotional distress, pain and suffering, and also the public’s willingness-to-pay costs (which include public concern about crime and willingness to assist in crime prevention) in order to capture the victim-specific and societal toll that is imposed by crime (Cohen et al. 1994, 2004). Aggregate total costs of crime (in the United States) have been estimated to be between $1 and $2 trillion (O’Brien 2010), which is likely an underestimate of the total costs because this includes only known crimes and excludes many white-collar/corporate crimes whose costs are in the mid-billions to low-trillions (Helmkamp, Townsend, and Sundra 1997; National White-Collar Crime Center 2003; Piquero, Cohen, and Piquero 2011).

Research on the monetary costs of crime using criminal career data has yielded several studies that have used different samples of offenders, offenses, and methodologies, and not surprisingly, cost estimates vary widely. One early attempt was completed by Cohen (1998), who calculated the various costs that a young career criminal would likely inflict over their criminal career. Including the annual victim and criminal justice-related costs per index crime, he found that the total external costs of a life of crime ranged from approximately $1.5 to $1.8 million. DeLisi and Gatling (2003) replicated Cohen’s study among a sample of 500 midwestern adult criminals with at least 30 career arrests and found that the average cost imposed per offender was more than $1.14 million. In a third study, Welsh et al. (2008) used data from the Pittsburgh Youth Study and found that the 10 percent most serious and chronic delinquent inner-city boys imposed about $800,000 to $900,000 in victim costs during adolescence.

Cohen and Piquero (2009) used data from the 1958 Philadelphia Birth Cohort Study to examine the costs of crime through the mid-20s. These authors presented the value of saving a high-risk youth (i.e., the preventive value indicating how much money and victimization would be saved if the offending career was forestalled) to be between $2.6 and $5.3 million at age 18. A key feature of their work was the use of public willingness-to-pay estimates that include public concern about crime (i.e., collateral costs that include crime prevention expenditures, avoidant behaviors, insurance costs, government welfare programs) and increases the costs associated with career offenders. These modifications served to produce higher cost estimates than those obtained in previous studies (Cohen and Piquero 2009:38).

In a follow-up study, Cohen, Piquero, and Jennings (2010a) estimated the costs of crime for offending trajectories in the same data and found that a group of chronic offenders who commit crimes frequently when young and who turned to more serious crimes as adults imposed far greater costs than low-frequency chronic offenders and a group of offenders whose offending peaked during adolescence. Several findings are noteworthy. First, the mean costs per offender in the high-rate group were over $1 million. Second, the costs of offending for the high-rate group were higher in early adulthood (age 18 to 26) than during adolescence (age 8 to 17). Third, the most frequent (high-rate chronic) offender (53 crimes) imposed a cost of $1,696,000 by the mid-20s. Finally, their findings indicated that preventing individuals from becoming high-rate chronic offenders would yield significant cost savings of upward of $200 million by the mid-20s. Subsequent analyses by Cohen, Piquero, and Jennings (2010b) exploring race/sex differences in trajectory cost estimates indicated that (1) male high-rate chronic offenders imposed costs of over half a billion dollars; (2) the average costs per one high-rate chronic male offender was greater than $1.5 million; (3) high-rate chronic African American offenders, who represented 2.7 percent of the sample imposed 36.3 percent of the total costs—more than $1.6 million per offender; and (4) high-rate chronic Hispanic offenders had a cost of over $200,000 per offender.

Finally, DeLisi et al. (2010) reported on the costs imposed among 654 convicted homicide offenders from eight U.S. states, finding that the average murderer imposed costs of about $24 million, while the most severe offender imposed a total cost of over $160 million. This cost is much higher than the average cost of a criminal career or high-risk delinquent youth ($1 to $5 million) previously reported—likely due to the use of a sample of convicted murderers.2

sec.title: Current Study
sec.p: This study extends prior work in several ways. First, we use longitudinal offending data for males in the Cambridge Study in Delinquent Development (CSDD), including previously identified offending trajectories (through age 40) as well as offending data obtained from an additional record search that offers an additional 10 years of data to age 50. Second, most cost-of-crime studies have been limited to the United States, and to the best of our knowledge there exists no cost-of-crime research employing criminal career/life course data at the individual-level outside the United States. As such our analysis is the first to examine the costs of a life course of crime in the United Kingdom, a country that has experienced significant crime and criminal justice system issues (Farrington and Jolliffe 2004, 2005a, 2005b). Finally, in order to examine whether distinct groups of offenders impose varying degrees of financial harm, we examine how the economic and social costs of crime are distributed across offender trajectory groups. Our data following a cohort of individuals into middle adulthood permit one of the most comprehensive investigations that examine the costs of crime across distinct offending trajectories and centering on costs per offender.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The CSDD is a prospective longitudinal survey of the development of antisocial behavior in 411 South London males (Farrington, Coid, and West 2009; Farrington et al. 2006). At the time they were first contacted in 1961/1962, they were all living in a working class area of South London. The sample included all boys then aged 8 to 9 and on the registers of six state primary schools within a one mile radius of a research office. The most common year of birth was 1953. In most cases, the family breadwinner at that time, usually the father had a working class occupation. Most subjects were White (97 percent) and of British origin. Ninety-five percent of the participants still reside in the United Kingdom. Findings from the CSDD have been documented in the literature (Farrington 2003; Piquero, Farrington, and Blumstein 2007).

sec.title: Convictions
sec.p: The measure of offending includes theft, theft from a motor vehicle, theft of a motor vehicle, sex offense, assault, robbery, burglary, and vandalism convictions.3 We use two different strands of conviction data. The first was used to form the offending trajectories described in Piquero et al. (2007) and came from a search of conviction records in the summer of 1994, when most males were aged 40.4 Searches were conducted in the central Criminal Record Office (National Identification Bureau) in London and later in the Police National Computer (PNC) records to try to locate findings of guilt (i.e., convictions). Convictions were counted for offenses committed up to the end of 1993. Between ages 10 and 16 inclusive (the years of juvenile delinquency in England at that time), 85 males were convicted. Up to age 40, 164 males were convicted (Farrington, Barnes, and Lambert 1996; Farrington, Lambert, and West 1998). The recorded age of offending is the age at which an offense was committed, not the age on conviction.

In 1994 and earlier, microfiche records were consulted in Scotland Yard. From 1995, the microfiche collection was discontinued and all convictions (and cautions) were recorded on the PNC. There was only limited copying of old records to the PNC, generally when a person received a new conviction. The latest searches of criminal records took place in July 2002 and December 2004, at which time the youngest man was aged 50 (Farrington et al. 2006).5 The analyses that follow combine with recent data collection (ages 41 to 50) to the trajectories identified by Piquero et al. (2007) in order to provide the most comprehensive individual-level criminal career data used to estimate the monetary costs of crime.

sec.title: Costs of individual crimes
sec.p: While there is debate surrounding the various methods for estimating the costs of crime (Cohen 2005), we derive our cost estimates from the British Home Office’s economics and resource analysis center as the sample resides in United Kingdom. Brand and Price (2000) published a report on the economic and social costs of crime in England and Wales, and these estimates take into account the cost of crimes on individuals, households, businesses and institutions, and society collectively. Thus, intangible costs such as costs related to trauma and physical injury are also incorporated into the estimates alongside the tangible costs, for example, the cost of a hospital bed. The following represents the dimensions of the costs that were originally used by Brand and Price (2000), updated to 2003 costs6 by Dubourg and Hamed (2005), and applied in the current study: (1) the anticipation of crime (security expenditures and insurance administration)7; (2) as a consequence of crime (property stolen and damaged, lost output, emotional and physical impact, health services, victim support services)8; and (3) in response to crime (police, prosecution, legal aid and nonlegally aided defense costs, magistrates and crown courts, probation service, prison service, jury service, and criminal injuries compensation resources).9 Further, we relied on the average costs of crime (Dubourg and Hamed 2005, Table 2.1) as these estimates focus on the individual incidents and permit a more direct comparison of the costs, on average, of one individual crime (e.g., robbery) relative to another crime (e.g., burglary). Using motor vehicle theft as an example, Dubourg and Hamed estimate the following costs (in U.K. £): defense expenditures (£546), insurance administration (£370), physical and emotional victim harm (£800), value of stolen property (£2,367), victim services (£1), lost work output (£47), and criminal justice system costs (£199; for additional cost breakdowns for each crime type see Dubourg and Hamed 2005, Table 2.1).

All cost estimates for each specific conviction for each subject were aggregated by year for each of the 41 years of follow-up (ages 10 to 50). Cost estimates are presented in U.K. currency (£) and for comparison are also converted to U.S. dollars ($) at the long-term average rate of 1.6 U.K. £ to the U.S. $.

sec.title: Analytic Strategy
sec.p: The analysis proceeds in several stages. First, the mean frequency of offending is updated for each of the five trajectories identified by Piquero et al. (2007) for ages 41 to 50. Second, the monetary costs associated with the specific crimes committed are estimated for each individual by age from ages 10 to 50. Third, bivariate comparisons examine how the mean and total costs of crime are distributed across the trajectories. Fourth, we highlight the extent of the high-rate chronic group’s offending frequency as well as the cost of their offending from ages 10 to 50. Finally, we compare the cost estimates from the prior U.S. studies to those of the present study.

sec.title: Offending Frequency of CSDD Trajectories from Age 41 to 50
sec.p: Figure 1 displays the offending trajectories from ages 10 to 40 and updated to age 50. The dotted lines represent the trajectories identified by Piquero et al. (2007) and the solid lines represent the updated mean offending frequency for each of the five trajectory groups from ages 41 to 50. As shown, the two groups of chronic offenders were still offending in their 40s. Not surprisingly, the nonoffenders and the low-rate adolescence peak offenders were still inactive in their 40s, but the high-rate adolescence peak group became active again in their 40s after nearly a decade of inactivity. It is also worth noting that in general, about 40 percent of the sample had accumulated at least one conviction by age 50 and 13.2 percent of the sample had a violent conviction (assault, robbery, sex offense), of which most were for assault. Not only did the high-rate chronics offend the most frequently (21.13 mean convictions; F = 590.73, p < .001) but they also had a greater prevalence (87.5 percent; F = 42.88, p < .001) and frequency (3.63 mean convictions; F = 84.80, p < .001) of violent convictions compared to all other offender groups.10

caption.p: CSDD offending trajectories from age 10 to 40 with additional follow-up to age 50.

sec.title: Costs of CSDD Trajectories from Age 10 to 50
sec.p: Figure 2 presents the mean costs of offending in £ from ages 10 to 50 by age and by group as well as the monetary cost estimates converted to $. A comprehensive monetary cost estimate was attached to each individual’s specific crime(s) that they committed from early adolescence into middle adulthood. All of these crime(s) specific costs were aggregated for each individual by age and subsequently aggregated for each trajectory by age. As expected, the monetary costs of offending for each group mirrors the trends in their offending frequency shown in Figure 1, that is, the ages at which the groups display a peak in their offending frequency also display a peak in their offending costs. Across all offender trajectories, the most costly stage of the life course is mid-to-late adolescence. Another important finding lies in the comparison of the frequency of offending and the costs of offending between the two high-rate groups during mid-to-late adolescence. Specifically, although the high adolescence peak offenders offend more frequently on average than the high-rate chronics, the high-rate chronics cost more due to their greater involvement in serious (and person-oriented) offenses.

caption.p: CSDD cost trajectories from age 10 to 50 by trajectory membership in U.K. pounds (£) and U.S. dollars ($).

sec.p: Figure 3 provides further illustration of the group-based trends in the monetary costs of crime where the age by year cost estimates were smoothed by creating 5-year averages for the costs of crime from ages 10 to 50 (with the exception that the final average cost, age 45 to 50, was based on a 6-year average). The solid black line represents the mean costs of offending for the sample from ages 10 to 50 in the aggregate and emphasizes the importance of disaggregating the costs across groups as the large amount of variability in the costs of crime are minimized and masked in the mere aggregate costs. As shown, there is a strong age/cost pattern that resembles the classic age/crime curve and peaks in adolescence. This suggests that the answer to whether the average cost of crime follows the aggregate age/crime curve depends on unpacking the trajectories and which group is being focused on. For most offender groups, the age/cost pattern tends to strongly peak in late adolescence, but for the high-rate chronics the costs appear to be high well into early adulthood and into middle adulthood.

caption.p: Five-year smoothed CSDD cost trajectories from age 10 to 50 by trajectory membership in U.K. pounds (£) and U.S. dollars ($).

sec.title: Mean and Total Cost Comparisons of CSDD Trajectories from Age 10 to 50
sec.p: Table 1 provides the mean cost of offending in each of the groups in U.K. £ and U.S. $ as well as the total costs of each trajectory. On average, the offending of one low adolescence peak offender costs $10,210 (£6,406) over the course of their criminal career measured from ages 10 to 50. Comparatively, very low-rate chronic offenders, on average, cost slightly more than twice as much ($21,576; £13,538) as low adolescence peak offenders whereas high adolescence peak offenders cost roughly four times as much ($40,933; £25,683) as low adolescence peak offenders. Finally, high-rate chronics, on average, impose higher costs compared to all the other groups ($95,241; £59,760). All of the mean costs presented in Table 1 and displayed in Figure 4 significantly varied across all of the trajectory comparisons.

sec.title: Costs of High-Rate Chronic Offenders
sec.p: Considering the attention that high-rate chronic offending receives in the literature (Moffitt 1993; Piquero 2008) and the substantial costs imposed by high-rate chronic offenders (Cohen et al. 2010a, 2010b; Cohen and Piquero 2009), it is important to explore these offenders further. First, on average, they accumulated slightly more than 21 convictions from ages 10 to 50. This is twice as much as the average number of convictions of the high adolescence peak offenders, 4 times as much as the average number of convictions of the very low-rate chronic offenders, and slightly more than 10 times as much as the average number of convictions of the low adolescence peak offenders. Second, this similar trend is also observed when comparing the mean costs of high-rate chronic offending with the other groups. This type of offending costs more than twice as much as high adolescence peak offending (in terms of average costs of an offender in the group), nearly four and a half times as much as very low-rate chronic offending, and more than nine times as much as low adolescence peak offending. Also, the most costly high-rate chronic offender imposed £96,201 ($153,318) in costs distributed across his criminal career from ages 10 to 50. This individual committed 17 crimes, of which 6 were person-oriented.

sec.title: Comparison of Cost Estimates from Previous U.S. Studies and the CSDD Study
sec.p: Table 2 provides a breakdown of the cost comparisons from prior U.S.-based studies and those derived from the present study by crime type. In general, the rank ordering of the most costly crimes are similar across studies (e.g., sexual offenses imposed the largest costs followed by assault, and theft and vandalism are the least costly of the crimes). Second, the cost estimates of the present study for specific crimes are most similar to those from Miller et al. (1996) whose estimates incorporated victim losses including medical care spending, mental health care spending, reduced quality of life, and tangible losses. Third, compared to the recent cost estimates provided in Cohen et al. (2010a), see Table 3, the present study’s cost estimates in magnitude are less comparable for person offenses than they are for property offenses. This can largely be explained by the fact that Cohen et al. (2010a) incorporated willingness-to-pay (WTP) costs, which are much higher for person offenses compared to property offenses. Finally, comparisons of mean group-based costs in the present study are similar to those from Cohen et al. (2010a). Specifically, on average, high-rate chronics imposed the most costs followed by the high adolescence peak offenders and the very low-rate chronics. Yet, in Cohen et al. (2010a), the costs of very low-rate chronics are roughly 4 to 7 times greater, the costs of high adolescence peak offenders are generally 10 to 22 times greater, and the costs of high-rate chronic offenders are about 5 to 10 times greater compared to the cost estimates in the present study.11

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Analysis of the monetary estimates of the cost of crime remains limited and international cost-of-crime research is sparse. This study used longitudinal data from the CSDD in order to produce cost-of-crime estimates to age 50. A focus on the costs of crime in the United Kingdom is of interest not only because of the lack of replication outside the United States but also because these data represent the most comprehensive monetary costs-of-crime individual-level analysis in the literature and because the costs of crime in the aggregate in England and Wales has been estimated to be around £60 billion (almost $100 billion) at 1999 prices (Brand and Price 2000). Several findings are highlighted.

First, when we investigated the average costs of offending by age and trajectory, we found that (1) the most costly stage of the life course is mid-to-late adolescence, where offense frequency also tends to peak; (2) during adolescence, high adolescence peak and high-rate chronic offender trajectories had similar offending frequencies, but the high-rate chronic group costs more because they also had more serious person-oriented offenses in their crime mix; and (3) total costs of crime were significantly different across offending trajectories, with high-rate chronic offenders costing the most (average high-rate chronic offender costs £59,760 or $95,241). Second, persons in the high-rate chronic group average 21 convictions to age 50 and the most costly offender in this group was convicted of 17 offenses (6 of which were serious person-oriented) and imposed a cost of £96,000 ($153,000). In short, the total aggregate monetary costs of offending among the offenders amounted to £2,042,297 ($3,254,935). Third, under the assumption that the prevalence of the male high-rate chronic group was representative of the prevalence of male high-rate chronic offenders in the United Kingdom specifically, then a male high-rate chronic offender on average would impose an annual cost of £18 ($29) per U.K. citizen or a lifetime cost of £742 ($1,185) per U.K. citizen (based on 2011 population estimates and regardless of age; Central Intelligence Agency 2011).12

As noted, only officially recorded crimes were included and thus the cost estimates are underestimated. Farrington et al. (2006; table 4.7) reported that the ratio of official convictions to self-reported offending over the life course for this sample was 1 to 38.7. If this ratio was applied to the male high-rate chronic group, then a male high-rate chronic offender’s “true” criminal career, on average, would impose a lifetime crime cost of £28,715 (£742 × 38.7; $45,865) per U.K. citizen or an annual crime cost of £700 ($1,118) per U.K. citizen.13 This scaling-up estimate suggests that our conviction-based estimates are a low bound estimate of the true costs of crime and that the real cost is likely to approximate the scaled-up version.14

Several limitations need to be considered. For example, the conviction data did not include costly white-collar/corporate crimes. White-collar/corporate occupations, uncommon in this sample, are not observed among the high-rate chronic offenders (Piquero, Piquero, and Farrington 2010). Also implicit in our estimates are the assumptions underlying the inputs into the cost figures across the respective crimes. One of these deals with accounting for the public’s willingness to pay for crime.15 Specifically, the cost estimates used in this study, which were derived from Brand and Price (2000) and Dubourg and Hamed (2005), are more similar to Cohen (1988) and Miller et al. (1996) that account for victim (intangible) losses but not society’s willingness to pay. Once again, therefore our cost estimates are conservative. Such limitations and cautions should be kept in mind when interpreting such figures. Other costs not previously considered (psychological costs to the victim, police protection costs to the criminal justice system, and costs borne by households and communities that seek to minimize the risk of victimization) might partially explain the differences that are observed across cost-of-crime studies. Given that high-rate chronics tend also to impose costs on society because of their lack of education and employment and adverse health (Piquero, Farrington, et al. 2010), the costs of their offending also entail costs that are independent of victim and criminal justice costs. These offenders, while small in number, likely contribute even more of a financial burden than previous and current estimates suggest. Adopting prevention and intervention strategies aimed at reducing the number of high-rate chronics and/or speeding up their eventual desistance will offer many savings to the public and perhaps turn those negative costs into positive contributions.

As an anonymous reviewer observed, overall cost estimates (and savings) need to be considered within a context, that is, a $200 million savings in the United States is very different from a $200 million savings in a specific city.

Since (at least until the 1970s) conviction in London was very likely after arrest, the requirement of conviction in London does not represent a major distinction from the arrest data which is the more commonly available official record data in the United States (Blumstein, Farrington, and Moitra 1985:194). The minimum age of criminal responsibility in England is 10. Juveniles between the 10th and 14th birthday are referred to as “children” and those between the 14th and 17th birthday (the minimum age for adult court at that time) are “young persons” (Blumstein et al. 1985:196).

A semiparametric mixed Poisson model was used to detect distinct trajectories to age 40 (Nagin 2005; Nagin and Piquero 2010) and a five-trajectory solution provided the best fit: (1) nonoffenders, (2) low adolescence peaked, (3) very low-rate chronics, (4) high adolescence peaked, and (5) high-rate chronics. A very small number of individuals imposed a large proportion of convictions (Piquero, Farrington, and Blumstein 2003). Only 28 of the 411 men were incarcerated at some point before the age of 40. The mean time served was 1.5 years. Initial analysis showed that incarceration did little to alter offending patterns, largely due to the infrequent use of incarceration and the little amount of time off the street among those who were incarcerated (Piquero et al. 2007:41).

Many records of old convictions were not found in the PNC and several convictions before 2002 were not found until the 2004 search, which covered National Identification Service (NIS) as well as PNC. The earliest date listed in the PNC was counted as the date on which an offense was committed. It was decided to count officially recorded cautions as well as convictions in the PNC, since cautions were routinely recorded on a national basis from 1995. In this study, then, convictions after age 40 include cautions. Also, the definition of what is a “standard list” offense changed over time. In particular, drunk driving offenses were added to the standard list from 1996 and 12 convictions for this offense were recorded. Due to changes in categorization over time, motoring offenses were excluded from analyses if they occurred after age 40.
Monetary units are based on a discounted net present value methodology recommended by the Home Office (HM) treasury at a rate of 3.5 percent.

The costs of security expenditures are derived by taking the annual expenditure on security measures that are spent in efforts to target the particular crime in question. This figure is then averaged over the estimated frequency of the specific crime in order to arrive at an average expenditure per crime. The cost of insurance administration is equivalent to premiums paid out, for example, a cost paid out to potential victims, minus the processed claims that were paid out, for example, a benefit paid out to the victims who were insured (Brand and Price 2000).

The value of stolen or damaged property is determined using replacement value estimates or repair costs. Lost output estimates are derived by multiplying the average wage rate by the amount of time taken off work as a result of being the victim of a crime. The emotional and physical impact of being a victim of crime are assessed using values that society places on the economic costs of preventing a victimization experience and its related pain and suffering derived from the Department of the Environment, Transport, and the Regions (1999) figures. Victim service costs are estimated using data on financial assistance given to victims and adjusted for an opportunity cost (e.g., the lost output of victim support workers who are volunteers who would be working if a victimization had not occurred; Brand and Price 2000).

Police costs are based on the proportion of the total annual police budget expenditures that are crime related. Other criminal justice system costs are determined by a complex computer model developed by the Home Office and the Lord Chancellor’s Department and the Crown Prosecution Services (Harries 1999) that reports how these costs are imposed throughout the criminal justice process by crime type (Brand and Price 2000).

It is important to bear in mind that cost-of-crime comparisons are difficult and complex to make due to the diversity in the methods for calculating the costs of crimes (McCollister, French, and Hai Fang 2010), the different research designs used, the time/year in which the cost estimates are based, the geographic location of the study, and the sources relied on to derive the estimates (self-report data, official data, government data). The differences in the magnitude of the cost estimates between Cohen et al.’s (2010a) study and the present study may be an artifact of these variabilities. In particular, the 1958 Philadelphia birth cohort was (1) larger than the CSDD (27,160 compared to 411); (2) included males and females; (3) had a higher prevalence of serious/violent offending; and (4) was comprised of several race/ethnic groups (Tracy, Wolfgang, and Figlio 1990). Also, the offending measure in the present study was conviction based, whereas Cohen et al. (2010a) used police contacts, which contain many more observations.

This crime cost is calculated using the following formula with the high-rate chronic offender group as an example: [2.5 percent (prevalence of male high-rate chronic offenders) × 31,118,895 (2011 U.K. male population) = 777,972 (total population of male high-rate chronic offenders) × £59,760 (average cost of a male high-rate chronic offender) = £46,491,606,720/62,698,362 (2011 U.K. total population) = £742 per U.K. citizen]. The annual crime cost is calculated by dividing the lifetime crime cost by the number of years of offending data available in the study (41 years).

Comparable scaled-up estimates for the other offending groups are low adolescence peak (£22,889; $36,559), high adolescence peak (£26,656; $42,576), and very low-rate chronic (£29,385; $46,935). Very low-rate chronics impose a crime cost that is slightly larger than the high-rate chronics, but this comparable estimate is largely driven by the fact that the very low-rate chronics are more than four times as prevalent as high-rate chronics.

An anonymous reviewer noted that caution should be exercised with interpreting these (potentially exaggerated) estimates because minor crimes go more unpunished than serious ones. Thus, applying the same cost per crime regardless of whether the crime was prosecuted leads to a cost of crime which is biased upward. Another point of caution deals with the sample. To the extent that the CSDD is focused on children with socioeconomic conditions correlated with offending, then the rate of chronic offenders in the sample would be much larger than in the U.K. population as a whole, thus biasing the estimate upward.

Caution should be exercised when interpreting the degree to which the public’s willingness to pay for crime has been incorporated into the monetary estimates reported here. Both Brand and Price (2000) and Dubourg and Hamed (2005) accounted for the public’s willingness to pay to avoid road traffic accidents using Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (1999) figures, which are assumed to increase as per capita income rises.
